summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary interview conducted by DOJ Office of the Inspector General agents with a Federal Bureau of Prisons employee, R. , who was the Lock and Security Supervisor at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The interview focuses on the circumstances surrounding the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein on August 9-10, 2019, specifically investigating camera malfunctions and staff responsibilities at the MCC during that time.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) and was pronounced dead, reportedly by hanging.

events.title: Camera System Failure
events.description: The camera system within the MCC, specifically in the area housing Epstein, was not working or recording properly. The com tech, Mr. , reportedly identified the issue but did not fix it that day.

events.description: The Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General conducts a voluntary, sworn interview with BOP employee R.  as part of its investigation into Epstein's death and surrounding circumstances.

keyFacts: The interview confirms that the camera system in the MCC was not working properly on August 9-10, 2019, when Jeffrey Epstein died.

The witness, R. , states he was never informed about the camera malfunction by the responsible com tech, Mr. , and believes it would have been unacceptable for staff to leave the facility knowing the cameras were down.
The witness's understanding of Epstein's death is that officers failed to do rounds, and Epstein hung himself. He suggests prevention could have involved suicide watch or a cellmate.
The witness identifies only a few staff (the com tech, electrician Maurice Ling, and the Facilities Manager) as having potential access to service or potentially disable the camera system.
The document is part of an official OIG investigation into "job performance failure and security failure" related to Epstein's death.
